item.title: Wizards of the Coast Announces Extended Partnership with TCGPlayer
item.content:encoded:
Wizards of the Coast is expanding their partnership with TCGPlayer. The Magic: The Gathering publisher will work alongside the virtual card marketplace for exclusive content designed to engage the dedicated enthusiast community.

According to the press release, Wizards of the Coast's TCGPlayer partnership is expanding from something offered earlier this year: the introduction of WPN badges to eligible TCGPlayer storefronts.

Now, Wizards of the Coast will offer exclusive content to the TCGPlayer community. This includes exclusive previews, interviews with game designers, and exclusive reveals. For convenience, users can filter search results to discover any Magic: The Gathering products held exclusively in WPN-verified stores.

TCGplayer is focused on innovating for our community, enhancing buyer and seller
experiences, and offering the best selection across trading card games,” said Stephanie Mims,
Senior Vice President, Seller Experience. “Being designated the preferred online marketplace
for the WPN represents a milestone in our quest to be the most trusted trading card platform for
Magic players and retailers.


Our investment in local game stores and the Wizards Play Network is at the core of this
initiative,” said Brian Trunk, Vice President of Wizards Commercial, Hobby and WPN at Wizards
of the Coast. “By teaming up with TCGplayer, we’re not only giving players greater confidence
in their purchases, but also empowering WPN retailers to thrive, reach new audiences, and
continue building strong Magic communities.

TCGPlayer is one of the largest virtual card retail platforms on the internet. The platform, acquired by eBay in early 2023 for the sum of $295 million, has helped dedicated card game players and aspirational competitive players obtain the cards they want for their respective game. Be it Magic: The Gathering, Disney Lorcana, or even the Pokemon TCG.

The platform recently came under fire due to it quickly shutting down an authentication center down in Syracuse. This was seen by the workers as an attempt to shut down the worker's union seeking better wages. This lead to a boycott starting in May 2025 before a new contract was renegotiated by the worker's union in June.

Ever since he was small, Tyler Chancey has had a deep, abiding love for video games and a tendency to think and overanalyze everything he enjoyed. This… More about Tyler

item.title: Tomb Raider Studio Crystal Dynamics Hit by Layoffs Again
item.content:encoded:
Tomb Raider developer Crystal Dynamics has announced yet another round of layoffs across "various departments and projects", and the layoffs are apparently an attempt to "restructure the company and business".

In a post on LinkedIn, Crystal Dynamics calls the decision to lay off "just under 30" employees a "difficult but necessary decision", and blames the evolving "realities of the industry" for the need to let more team members go.

The studio says that the layoffs are an attempt to "optimize the continued development of [its] flagship Tomb Raider game", in addition to "shaping the rest of the studio to make new games for the future".

This is the third time that Crystal Dynamics has engaged in layoffs this year; it first laid off a round of employees in March, then again in August following the cancellation of Xbox's Perfect Dark reboot (and the shuttering of the studio chiefly responsible for making it).

At the time of August's layoffs, Crystal Dynamics reassured fans that Tomb Raider's development was "unaffected" by the decision. Technically, no such reassurance has been offered for this latest wave of redundancies.

It's also worth noting that the next game in the Tomb Raider series has yet to be announced; there's an Amazon series headed up by Fleabag's Phoebe Waller-Bridge in the works, but that's the only piece of genuinely new Tomb Raider media fans have to cling to for now.

As far as we know, the as-yet-unrevealed Tomb Raider title is the only thing on which Crystal Dynamics is actively working, so I'd imagine there's quite a lot of pressure within the studio to deliver on this one (although what exactly "this one" is, we don't yet know).

We still don't have anything approaching an idea of when a new Tomb Raider game might be revealed, either; Crystal Dynamics simply says it "look[s] forward to sharing the team's amazing new work with the world in the future". Until then, stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph



https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/crystal-dynamics-layoffs-november-2025

item.title: Misery Returns to Steam Following Stalker 2 Dev's DMCA Claim
item.content:encoded:
Misery developer Platypus Entertainment has announced that the game has made a return to Steam, following a DMCA claim that was issued by Stalker 2 developer GSC Game World.

In a news post on Steam, the studio says that it has "resolved" the "misunderstanding" it had with GSC Game World, following a conversation with one of the Ukrainian developer's lawyers.

Specifically, Platypus makes reference to two issues it says were "not mentioned in the DMCA claim" and that the studio wasn't aware of. Both issues have now been resolved, and it seems like that's what has allowed Misery to be reinstated on Steam.

The first issue revolved around a "helicopter model in the files" of Misery. Platypus says the game is "an evolution of education, non-commercial projects", and that the model, which has now been removed, "was unintentionally left in [Misery''s] resources as a legacy leftover".

Platypus goes on to say that the helicopter model in question can't be seen anywhere in Misery itself, but the studio doesn't actually state exactly where it got the model from. Still, this appears to be one of the key points of contention for GSC Game World.

The second point pertains to some of the guitar-based folk songs being played in Misery. Platypus says that for the Stalker games, GSC Game World "used popular folk songs" for ambient guitar-playing NPCs, and that someone affiliated with Platypus "wrote original covers of some of these songs".

However, it turns out that some of the songs used by Platypus "were specifically written or exclusively licensed by GSC", so those songs have been removed. However, the studio is adamant that "no original files from GSC games were used".

If you need a reminder, Misery was taken down from Steam earlier this week following a DMCA claim by Stalker 2's GSC Game World, which alleged that Platypus Entertainment's game infringed GSC's copyright.

This led to a rather unfortunately slur-laden Discord message from developer Maewing, who subsequently apologized for their "past words" and "old posts", although that doesn't really apply to a message that was clearly posted after the strike was filed.

That, however, is an issue that Platypus has addressed in its most recent Steam news post; the studio says it has "established a strict policy on Discord moderation", which means it's no longer an "anarchy dumpster fire".

In any case, if you'd like to check out Misery, you can do so right now on PC via Steam. Stay tuned for more on this.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
